title: Catalytic Reductive Aminolysis of Reducing Sugars: Elucidation of Reaction Mechanism

reactions.text: The production of N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylene-diamine (TMEDA) and the corresponding evolution of the reaction temperature and total pressure are presented in Figure 1 for both the reductive aminolysis of glucose (diamonds) and for the reaction of sorbitol (squares) with dimethylamine (DMA) in the presence of Ru/C under hydrogen atmosphere. The product yield, given in C%, represents the fraction of carbon originating from the sugar substrate that is found in the final product.

The carbon supported Pd (entry 25), however, produced a translucent product mixture, indicating no competitive Maillard and/or caramelization. The main reaction product for this catalyst was N,N-dimethylglucamine (71 C%), which is the result of a reductive amination of glucose without C–C scission. In addition, 8 C% 4-dimethylamino-butane-1,2,3-triol was obtained, hereby completely closing the carbon balance.

Next, the hemiaminal IM (2) reacts into a zwitterionic iminium species (3) via dehydration at the hemiaminal C atom. If the iminium species (3) is primary or secondary (R1 = H), intramolecular proton transfer (PT) from the positive nitrogen ion to the negative oxygen ion results in the formation of a more stable imine (10). If the iminium species (3) is tertiary (R1 ≠ H, R2 ≠ H), intramolecular PT from the αC atom to the negative oxygen ion results in the formation of an enamine (10).

Aldopentoses such as xylose, arabinose, and ribose were also converted into TMEDA (34 C%, 30 C%, and 24 C% respectively), albeit with lower yields than the hexoses (compare entries 6–8 to 9–11). Instead, more C3 amines were formed because the C5 sugar is split into C2 and C3 fragments in agreement with the proposed mechanism (Scheme 1). However, more C2 amines (36 C% vs 29 C%) and less C3 amines (24 C% vs 31 C%) were produced from xylose for the MeOH reaction, compared to the H2O reaction.

To further examine the effect of the solvent, reductive glucose aminolysis was carried out under exactly the same reaction conditions, but in THF instead of MeOH. Surprisingly, only 23 C% TMEDA could be obtained for the THF reaction at full glucose conversion, compared to 66 C% for the same reaction in MeOH.

Kinetic experiments, presented in Figure 6, demonstrate that formation of TMEDA is faster in the presence MeOH compared to in THF alone. Upon replacing 5 g of THF into 5 g of MeOH, without altering the molar DMA excess, TMEDA is indeed produced considerably faster (Figure 6A). In presence of MeOH, 30 C% TMEDA is obtained already after 25 min, instead of 12 C% TMEDA in the absence of MeOH. For THF alone, 23 C% TMEDA was obtained after 1 h. Extension of the reaction time to 2 h did not result in higher TMEDA yield (see Figure S7, SI). Instead, 52 C% TMEDA was obtained in the presence of MeOH after 1 h. Figure 6B shows the same trend for reactions with a gradual increase of the methanol content.

reactions.text: Indeed, when the reaction of glucose with MEOA was carried out in two steps, first under N2 and then under H2 (Table 3, entry 3), both at 130 °C in the presence of Ni-6458P and in the same reaction vessel, an impressive BHEDMEDA yield of 92 C% was obtained.

Finally, the detrimental effect of H2O on the formation of the desired C2 amines was further confirmed for the reductive aminolysis of glucose with MEOA. When the amount of H2O in the reaction mixture was increased without changing the molar MEOA-to-glucose excess, systematically less BHEDMEDA was produced at higher H2O loading. This is illustrated in Figure 8.
